video.title: Shadow of the Tomb Raider (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
Ah, what a delightful thing it always is to
see a video game enter the hallowed ranks
of things that have shadows.

Now, as well as the colossus, the beast, the
damned, the comet, Mordor, and, erm, the beast
2, there&#39;s also a shadow of the Tomb Raider.

You might say it&#39;s just falling back on hackneyed
titling cliches because they already used

the generic R-word sequel name with Rise of
the Tomb Raider, but shadows are important.

A shadow can tell you how fat and ugly something
is without you having to directly look at
it.

And that&#39;s as fitting a segue into the actual
game as we&#39;re going to get.

Shadow of the Tomb Raider is the origin story
for how Lara Croft became a Tomb Raider, which

might confuse anyone who played the last two
Tomb Raiders which also claimed to be that
exact thing.
Apparently it was a trilogy all along.
Surprise!

I guess you need the full extent of three
games to fully establish why a person might

want to hunt for treasures and murder people
who are trying to murder them.

The plot for this one is - oh god it hardly
matters.

Lara&#39;s on a treasure hunt, needs to get to
the ancient ruins before the bad guys do because

the bad guys wouldn&#39;t treat them respectfully
or something.

As opposed to Lara, who just accidentally
demolishes most of it by climbing all over
it with her big fat arse.

She picks up a treasure that sets off the
countdown to apocalypse and the bad guys call

her a stupid fuck as natural disasters start
killing off all the locals and it&#39;s completely

her fault, but you have to have sympathy for
her because ages ago her father died and made
her quite sad.

And alone with nothing to her name but all
the money in the universe.

Anyway everyone sort of forgets about that
apocalypse thing and the plot becomes about

tracking down a lost city of Incas and durble
durble dum and at the end we&#39;re too late to

stop the main bad guy using the ancient magic
treasure to turn themselves into a god, the

kind of god who walks very slowly around a
boss arena and can be killed by shooting them
with bullets.

Yeah, Lara, I guess it was important we stop
them acquiring this unstoppable power.

They might have marched on Washington and
been instantly cut down by the national guard.

I&#39;m sure all those dead Mexicans now understand
the importance of their sacrifice, you mad
cow.

Well, now the origin story&#39;s officially over
I can state with complete confidence that
I can&#39;t stand this version of Lara Croft.

Admittedly old Lara Croft seemed to have augmented
her tits and bum by extracting material from

her personality but at least there was a sense
of fun, even falling nine storeys onto spikes

had this colourful bonhomie about it when
her pony tail was dancing merrily about her

exposed giblets like Francis Bacon&#39;s favourite
brush.

New Lara is just equal parts boring and apparently
psychotic.

First most of her emotional range got blasted
off her face in a hideous leaf blower accident

so she reacts to everything from an exploding
oil refinery to the death of her pet badger

like she&#39;s at the supermarket trying to figure
out what kind of toothpaste she wants.

Just like last time she&#39;s got a bad case of
the &#39;have tos&#39; and if you take a drink every

time she declares that she &#39;has to&#39; or &#39;must&#39;
do something then you&#39;ll wake up in a dog

kennel with your mouth tasting like the inside
of a cement mixer.

Which again gives her the personal agency
of a wooden ducky on a string.
And let&#39;s not forget she&#39;s bugfuck nuts.

Villager says &quot;Some naughty criminals are
giving us trouble!&quot;

Lara says &quot;Oh how terrible I MUST help you&quot;
and then with no further questions proceeds

to start wordlessly dragging people into bushes
and slitting their throats like she&#39;s been

waiting all fucking day for the excuse to
get started.

Help me out here, viewers - how has Lara Croft&#39;s
character developed over the course of this
developmental origin story?

She was already a super gymnast adventurer
archery gold medalist when the first game
started.

She had a brief case of the wibblies after
her first confirmed kill but she was chalking
them up like a champ inside ten minutes.

She has received a lot of punishment, but
if getting the shit beaten out of you is enough

to make you a complex and interesting character
then my knob deserves its own Scorsese-directed
biopic.

Mostly it seems she goes after treasures because
someone else getting it first would be bad

in some poorly established way, and then proceeds
to monotone her way through the subsequent
peril.

There is the occasional blip of character
development that is always quickly squashed
like a bubble in wallpaper.

On around twelve occasions she thinks she&#39;s
gotten her big dumb friend killed and starts

wondering if maybe this is why nobody comes
to her birthday parties but oh, turns out
he&#39;s alive, abort character development.

Then she thinks the baddies have killed her
big dumb friend so she puts on her terminator

face and goes on a rampage but again, oh,
big dumb friend still alive, back to sanity.

Big dumb friend almost gets through at one
point by yelling at her to stop shouldering

the whole burden and making things all about
her, shortly before she shoulders the whole
burden and makes things all about her.

The only revelation she seems to have had
by the end of her origin story is that maybe

she should stop bothering with the big dumb
friend in future.

Oh yeah, and there&#39;s this business with avenging
her father who was killed by the evil cult

conspiracy organisation thing we&#39;re up against,
but she isn&#39;t even sure they did kill him

until right at the end and most of the leaders
of the evil cult all die offscreen.

Which was probably the highlight of the game,
comedy-wise.

There&#39;s this action-packed penultimate battle
sequence before the final boss where an easily

missed voice over goes &quot;Hey, I&#39;ve got all
the cult leaders in this helicopter, whoops,
it crashed and everyone died.
Butterfingers.&quot;

Then the secondary villain dies, then the
main villain dies.
This is all in, like, ten minutes.

Not so much tying up the plot threads as taking
a fucking hedge trimmer to them.

I don&#39;t know if this is coming across but
I really didn&#39;t like Shadow of the Tomb Raider
very much.

I consider it fitting that it used an eclipse
as its symbol because creatively speaking
it&#39;s a fucking black hole.

The only new idea it had for the gameplay
was that now you can hide on plant-covered
walls as part of the stealth.
I assume this was the result of nepotism.

Mr. Chest high wall pressured Square Enix
to give his layabout cousin a job so he&#39;d
get off the weed.

It&#39;s one of those games where I had real trouble
deciding what upgrades to buy from the character

menu because they all seemed equally useless
as long as stealth kills still work and most

enemies go down in a mere smattering of bullets
from the assault rifle you are given at no
cost.

Increase the amount of time Lara can hold
her breath underwater?

I don&#39;t see how you could increase it by much,
she&#39;s already putting pearl divers to shame.

She must have a couple of air pockets concealed
in her bra.

Speaking of which, did you see that bit in
the trailer where Lara&#39;s struggling to squeeze

her D-cups through an incredibly narrow underwater
cave before she drowns?
Effective moment, that, wasn&#39;t it?

Devs clearly thought so, they reuse it like
four times.

Not that there&#39;s any actual peril, it&#39;s an
altogether now predetermined action set piece
like half the rest of the game.

Which is probably why the game world feels
so shallow and artificial.

There is a modern-style oil refinery literally
within a minute&#39;s brisk walk of the secret

Incan city for no better reason than to have
something Lara can blow up at the start of
the final act.

Which she does within about thirty seconds
of arriving at it.
What do you expect?
She&#39;s an outdoorswoman.
She likes hiking.
Insurance rates.
Ha ha ha HA ha.
